Description: Limestone or chalk figure of a crouching dog or panther. The front paws are crossed, the tail between legs, the head is facing backwards. The fine teatment of the limbs and face suggest it was intended to represent a greyhound or similar dog. A brown residue, may be paint. The right side of the face is chipped.
Curator's comments: Small stone dog sculptures are rare at Naukratis (British Museum 1888,0601.49) though a larger example is also known from Naukratis (Cairo (JE27200). Two stylised Anubis dogs (Boston 86.178, 86.179), have parallels from Saqqara (Jeffreys & Smith 1988, pl. 26a, 78/226, see also pl. 41e-f, pl. 16a-d) and Yusef, Goshen (Dundee MacManus Galleries, 1975-225).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (CE.202) (Phase 3)
